inlineContent.text: contains a set of glyphs to represent Unicode characters imported from a font file, as well as a cache of rasterized glyphs, and a set of fallback
to access specific OpenType variation of the font, create simulated bold / slanted version, and draw lines of text.
For more complex text processing, use
Dynamic font importer: TrueType (.ttf), TrueType collection (.ttc), OpenType (.otf), OpenType collection (.otc), WOFF (.woff), WOFF2 (.woff2), Type 1 (.pfb, .pfm).
Bitmap font importer: AngelCode BMFont (.fnt, .font), text and binary (version 3) format variants.
Monospace image font importer: All supported image formats.
A character is a symbol that represents an item (letter, digit etc.) in an abstract way.
A glyph is a bitmap or a shape used to draw one or more characters in a context-dependent manner. Glyph indices are bound to the specific font data source.
If none of the font data sources contain glyphs for a character used in a string, the character in question will be replaced with a box displaying its hexadecimal code.

If set to

, glyphs of all sizes are rendered using single multichannel signed distance field (MSDF) generated from the dynamic font vector data. Since this approach does not rely on rasterizing the font every time its size changes, this allows for resizing the font in real-time without any performance penalty. Text will also not look grainy for
s that are scaled down (or for
s viewed from a long distance). As a downside, font hinting is not available with MSDF. The lack of font hinting may result in less crisp and less readable fonts at small sizes.
